did.unittitle: Mill Creek Research Council, inc. records 1960-1988
did.abstract: Citizen action group formed in 1964-1965 by Mrs. Virginia Denham to oppose the flooding of the Mill Creek area in Lima Township, Washtenaw County, Michigan, to improve sewage treatment for communities downstream on the Huron River. The organization also opposed creation of a Mill Creek Metropark by the Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority an developed the South Lima Township Historical District plan. Correspondence, environmental impact statements, administrative files, newsletters, newspaper articles, topical files, maps, and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The Mill Creek Research Council record group (Donor no. 6266) was donated by the organization's board through its chairperson, Mrs. Virginia Denham, in July 1982 and October 1993 and by Mr. David Bacon (Donor no. 8527) in November 1996

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Mill Creek Research Council, Inc., Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Mill Creek Research Council (MCRC) is an environmental action group based in Lima Township, Washtenaw County, and was organized by Mrs. Virginia Denham. The MCRC was formed in 1964-1965 to protest a proposal by the United States Army Corps of Engineers to flood the Mill Creek area in order to provide better sewage treatment for communities downstream on the Huron River. The plan promoted by the Corps of Engineers was successfully opposed by the Research Council.

In 1965 the MCRC also organized to fight a proposal by the Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority (HCMA) to construct a 4,000-acre metropark, including a 1,500-acre lake that would be created by damming up Mill Creek. HCMA abandoned the plan in 1982, due to local opposition to condemning the land in question. HCMA was not sure if it had the power to condemn the land, and MCRC persuaded them not to investigate.

The residents remained suspicious of the HCMA, and in the early 1970s they created the South Lima Township Historical District plan. The plan's goal was to survey the township and apply for historical district status with the National Register of Historical Places. A 9,400-acre tract in Lima Township, South of I-94, was identified. The desire of the historical district council was to preserve the appearance of a 19th Century rural community in the tract.
The Michigan Department of State and the federal government determined that the tract was eligible for historical district status, and if it was registered would be the largest of its kind.

In July 1981 a proposal to preserve the tract was sent for review to the federal government, the Michigan Department of State and the National Park Service. A hearing was held by the history division of the Michigan Department of State in Lansing in April 1983. Ten people testified in favor of registration and two testified against it. The decision on the status of the historic district was then sent to the National Park Service in Washington, D.C for further investigation and approval.

A local couple, the Urquharts, who opposed the opportunity for federal intervention that registration as an historical district would allow, began an effort to block registration. They convinced a majority of 160 of 253 owners to send notarized affidavits of opposition to the government. Under the regulations, if a majority of the land/property owners in the district oppose registration, it can not be approved.

On September 8, 1983 the National Register of Historic Places reviewed the application and accidentally approved the registration. The decision was reversed in February 1984, after the mistake was revealed.
In the 1980s, the HCMA attempted to build a golf course in South Lima Township. The MCRC again prevented the action.

scopecontent.p: The U.S Army Corps of Engineers series, 1965-1970 (2.2 linear feet), deals with the first dispute in the 1960s to flood the Mill Creek area to improve sewage treatment on the Huron River. The series includes correspondence, clippings, and reports and audio-tapes of meetings.

did.unittitle: Washtenaw County Water Supply and Sanitary Sewage Systems
Water Resources Study, Huron River Basin, Michigan, U.S. Health, Education and Welfare

scopecontent.p: The Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Association series, 1969-1975 (3 linear feet), pertains to the dispute to create a metropark. It consists of correspondence, environmental impact statements, maps, student reports, administrative files, newsletters, newspaper articles, and topical files. After the Metropark project was abandoned, the Mill Creek Research Council continued to watch and collect material about the activities of the HCMA. Some of this material is included.

did.unittitle: 1975 Bureau of Outdoor Recreation, preliminary draft
Detroit Five County Area Parks and Recreation Study 1973
Hydrologic Study of the proposed Mill Creek Dam and Lake 1971
Washtenaw County Metro Planning Commission Report 1971
Johnson, Johnson and Roy (JJR) Planning Landscape Architects
"A Plan of Water and Sewage System Development," undated
"A Report on the Problems arising from Impounded Waters," undated
"A Study of the Proposed Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority Mill Creek Park," 1971
"Effects of the Proposed Mill Creek Park on the Chelsea School District," 1971
"Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority Mill Creek Metropark Preliminary Design Report Impoundments and Sanitary Facilities," 1974

scopecontent.p: The South Lima Historical District series, 1970-1993 (3.4 linear feet), contains the research and correspondence generated as the MCRC pursued registration as an historical district. The council received several grants to perform its survey of the land and property in the township. The paperwork leading up to the grants is included, as well as the reports of findings. These reports contain comprehensive descriptions of the township and its history. The surveyors classified each property in the reports, and included many photographs, some of which are artistic in quality. The collection of photographs and surveys are well indexed, and many maps will help researchers locate the land and property in question. In order to maintain continuity, the photographs that were taken for the surveys have not been separated from the paperwork. In many cases, the negatives for pictures are included as well.

Before the survey was conducted, the township was divided into quadrants that were labeled "A,B,C,D". Each quadrant was color-coded: yellow, red, green, blue, respectively. After the survey was completed, the farmhouses in the survey were classified according to their ability to preserve the appearance of a 19th Century rural community. The classifications were called "significant, contributing, neutral and non-contributing." These were also labeled in the report as groups "A,B,C,D", respectively.

did.unittitle: "Jerusalem Mill Area Survey of Lima Township," undated
"Lima Township: a study of rural character," 1974

scopecontent.p: The quadrant surveys files include a barn survey and descriptions and photographs of homes in each quadrant in the township

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials files include aerial photos, photographs and negatives of homes, barns, land features, farm animals, and some people from around Lima Township.

(many are labeled and are indexed with negatives)

scopecontent.p: The Zoning series, 1963-1988 (.2 linear feet) contains correspondence clippings and reports about zoning ordinances and issues in Lima Township.

did.unittitle: "Summary Outline of the Preliminary Draft Lima Township Zoning Ordinance," 1973

scopecontent.p: The Related Organizations series, 1969-1987 (.3 linear feet) contains material from other organizations in Washtenaw County that concern the Mill Creek Research Council. In some cases these organizations were affiliated with the Mill Creek Research Council. In other cases, some of the members of the Mill Creek Research Council were also prominent members of these related organizations.

did.unittitle: Comprehensive and Open Space System undated
Inventory of Recreational Lands and Facilities in Washtenaw County Michigan 1970
Land Use Policy for Washtenaw County (Preliminary) 1976
Water Resources for Washtenaw County Michigan 1976

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series, 1964-1977 (.3 linear feet) includes some administrative material from the Mill Creek Research Council as well as reports and legislation on a number of environmental issues.

did.unittitle: National Cooperative Soil Survey Soils of Washtenaw County undated
